title: Being Hospitalized Changed Everything for Me

content: In 2016, during my senior year of college, I went through one of the darkest periods of my mental health journey. I was truly financially independent for the first time, finishing my degree, working 50+ hours per week between two retail jobs, and trying to manage all the new adult responsibilities on my plate. Health care costs, for one, became a new expense for me — one that I couldn’t afford.

My bipolar disorder and anxiety had previously been treated with financial help from my parents, but that was no longer the case in 2016. Paying for psychiatry appointments to get my medications refilled every three months wasn’t feasible anymore, and this quickly became an issue when I began my fall semester in 2016. I figured I could last a while off my medications while I figured things out or saved up money, and that plan backfired in a major way.

On Oct. 1, 2016, I attempted to take my own life after battling a severe depressive episode for months. Thankfully, I was taken to the hospital by my best friend and ended up being held there under the Baker Act, the psychiatric hold law here in Florida. I wasn’t able to access my phone or leave the hospital for 72 hours.

content: This was my first experience with a real psychiatric emergency, and I was both terrified and humiliated. I also felt powerless and even resentful. My parents had withdrawn their financial assistance for my medical care because I decided to move into an apartment in a trendy neighborhood closer to my college instead of living at home to save money. They didn’t agree with the irresponsibility in that decision.
Instead of seeing things from their perspective, I chose to shift blame.
“See? This is what happens when I can’t afford my medicine,” I remember saying to my parents as they stood in my hospital room crying.

I feel incredibly embarrassed and childish thinking about that moment now. Although not being able to afford medical care on my own did play a role in my hospitalization, it wasn’t entirely the cause. My hospital stay put that in perspective.

content: I met a lot of other patients from all backgrounds and walks of life. Some were grandparents, some were there for eating disorders, and others were single mothers. A few patients regularly checked into the hospital because they were homeless, and it provided a safe place to sleep, shower, and eat.

content: Talking to and getting to know the other patients during group therapy or meals made a huge impact on me, especially when it came to my ingratitude or frustrations about my situation. One patient said she was about to lose custody of her children, and once she checked into the hospital, her husband called and asked for a divorce. Another patient told me he planned to take his own life as soon as he was released from the hospital.

Meanwhile, I was a student at a private university, studying musical theatre and constantly surrounded by a huge group of loving family and friends. I received so many calls and visits from my people that even the staff commented on how lucky I was to have that support. When I compared my experience and position in life to the other patients around me, I seemed like a spoiled brat who had no idea how good she had it.

Although experiencing a psychiatric hold was an incredibly hard and scary experience, it changed my entire life. My official mental health diagnosis was changed from mood disorder not otherwise specified to bipolar II disorder, which helped both me and my psychiatrist better understand my symptoms and how to treat them. That alone literally saved my life.

content: Dealing with a lifelong condition like bipolar disorder is never easy. I know that I will go through rough periods and probably have more depressive or hypomanic episodes. Still, perspective is incredibly important, especially when you’re like me: someone who has never walked that path alone and has always had a network of support and love around me.
